title.narrative: 1.MATERNAL NEWBORN AND CHILD HEALTH

description.narrative: By 2022, health workers have competencies to deliver quality integrated health services to mothers and new-borns in the five priority regions., which contributes to Fast-Track The End Of Hiv/Aids, Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence, Immunization Services As Part Of Primary Health Care, Maternal And Newborn Health, Strengthening Primary Health Care And High-Impact Health Interventions. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: by 2022, Women of childbearing age, pregnant women, newborns, boys and girls under age 5 years and adolescents use quality health services at health facilities and in communities.

sector.narrative: Community and home based maternal and newborn care
Facility based maternal and newborn care (including emergency obstetric and newborn care, quality improvement)
HIV testing and counselling including EID, POC EID, PITC, ANC testing, Self testing, Retesting and Family based testing
IMNCI facilities and referral level management of childhood illnesses (e.g. ETAT, inpatient care)
Implementation of community based integrated prevention and management of childhood illnesses (e.g. iCCM)
Maternal and newborn care policy advocacy, evidence generation, national / subnational capacity development

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2022, health workers have competencies to deliver quality integrated health services to mothers and new-borns in the fivepriority regions.

description.narrative: Two million children benefited from integrated management of childhood illnesses by CHWs, and 695,726 children aged from 0 to 11 months received Pentavalent 3 vaccines and 1,980,983 children aged 3 to 5 years were vaccinated against polio. In addition, 312,653 newborns received essential care in seven supported regions and 5,743 sick or small newborns received specific care;; 4,007,471 children aged between 3 months and 5 years were reached during malaria seasonal chemoprevention (SMC) campaign. Among 747,030 pregnant women tested for HIV in antenatal consultations 3,237 were positive and received antiretroviral treatment for prevention of mother to child transmission. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:28/01/2022
